sen.j: 寒稽古（かんげいこ）とは、寒の時期に、武道や芸事の修練を行うこと。
sen.e: The term Kangeiko means training of budo (martial art) or geigoto (accomplishment) conducted in mid-winter season.

sen.j: 技術の向上とともに、寒さに耐えながら稽古をやり遂げることで、精神の鍛錬をするという目的にも重きをおかれて行われるものである。
sen.e: By carrying out training while enduring coldness, it aims not only to improve skills but also to discipline one's mind.

sen.j: 一番寒い未明から明け方の時間に行われる。
sen.e: It is conducted during the coldest time zone of a day, before dawn or at dawn.
It is conducted during the coldest time of day, before dawn or at dawn.

sen.j: 昨今は社会・生活背景などもあって、暦の上での大寒の前後に行われる稽古を指す。
sen.e: Under the current social/daily life situation, it refers to the trainings conducted around the time of daikan (one of the twenty-four divisions of four seasons, and the coldest period in winter).

sen.j: また神道や修験道、仏教の一部などで寒修行または寒行と称して、海・川などの水に入る、或いは滝に打たれるなどをして精神を鍛錬している事から、武道の寒稽古でこれを取り入れている事も多い。
sen.e: As Shinto religion, Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism) and some sects of Buddhism incorporate ascetic practices like bathing in the sea/river or standing under a waterfall, called kanshugyo or kangyo, with the aim of mental training, Kangeiko of budo often incorporate such exercises.

sen.j: 武道では極限状態まで自らの身体・精神を追い込み、そこで自らの弱さに打ち勝ち(克己)自らの前途を開くことを一つの眼目としている。
sen.e: One of Budo's main purpose is to overcome one's weakness (self-governing) as well as to pave the way for the future by driving one's body/mind to an extreme situation.

sen.e: Also, Kangeiko is one of the few vanishing characteristics of budo.
